title: Law, war and the state of the American exception
abstractText:
The controversy surrounding America's war on terror is driven in part by the Bush administration's attitude to international law.  It claimed that the 9-11 attacks ushered in what the German legal philosopher Carl Schmitt called 'a state of exception'.  In the post-9/11 world, the US would claim an exception to the rules that otherwise governed warfare in order to justify policies such as pre-emptive self-defence, indefinite detention, and aggressive interrogation or torture.

This research explores the exact nature of these claims and their political significance in the post-Bush era.  It asks whether the 'state of exception' has been used as a means of justifying policies that responded to the pre-9/11 ideological goal of American neoconservativism, which is to maintain an image of America as an exceptional nation.

The project is interested in discovering how the Obama administration answers these questions and how those answers inform US national security policy after President Bush. To the extent exceptionalist thinking was significant during the Bush administration, and to the extent it informs US policy afterwards, this project also explores the impact it has had on our understanding of war as an institution of international society.
